sentences.sentence: The little prince crossed the desert and met with only one flower.
It was a flower with three petals( 花瓣 ), a flower of no account( 不重要的 ) at all.
“Good morning,” said the little prince.
“Good morning,” said the flower.
“Where are the men?” the little prince asked, politely.
The flower had once seen a caravan( 商队 ) passing.
“Men?” she echoed( 重复 ). “I think there are six or seven of them in existence. I saw them, several years ago. But one never knows where to find them.
The wind blows them away. They have no roots, and that makes their life very difficult.”
“Goodbye,” said the little prince.
“Goodbye,” said the flower.
After that, the little prince climbed a high mountain.
The only mountains he had ever known were the three volcanoes( 火山 ), which came up to( 达到 ) his knees.
And he used the extinct volcano( 死火山 ) as a footstool( 脚凳 ).
“From a mountain as high as this one,” he said to himself, “I shall be able to see the whole planet at one glance, and all the people . . .”
But he saw nothing, save peaks( 山顶 ) of rock that were sharpened( 削尖的 ) like needles.
“Good morning,” he said courteously( 有礼貌地 ).
“Good morning—Good morning—Good morning,” answered the echo( 回声 ).
“Who are you?” said the little prince.
“Who are you—Who are you—Who are you?” answered the echo( 回声 ).
“Be my friends. I am all alone,” he said.
“I am all alone—all alone—all alone,” answered the echo( 回声 ).
“What a queer( 奇怪的 ) planet!” he thought. “It is altogether dry, and altogether pointed, and altogether harsh( 恶劣的 ) and forbidding( 令人生畏的 ).
And the people have no imagination. They repeat whatever one says to them . . . On my planet I had a flower; she always was the first to speak . . .”
But it happened that after walking for a long time through sand, and rocks, and snow, the little prince at last came upon a road.
And all roads lead to the abodes( 住所 ) of men.
“Good morning,” he said.
He was standing before a garden, all abloom( 开满花的 ) with roses.
“Good morning,” said the roses.
The little prince gazed( 凝视 ) at them. They all looked like his flower.
“Who are you?” he demanded, thunderstruck( 大吃一惊的 ).
“We are roses,” the roses said.
And he was overcome with( 被...所控制 ) sadness.
His flower had told him that she was the only one of her kind in all the universe.
And here were five thousand of them, all alike, in one single garden!
“She would be very much annoyed,” he said to himself,
“if she should see that . . . she would cough most dreadfully( 极其严重地 ), and she would pretend that she was dying, to avoid being laughed at( 被嘲笑 ).
And I should be obliged to( 不得不 ) pretend that I was nursing her back to life—for if I did not do that, to humble( 使谦卑 ) myself also, she would really allow herself to die . . .”
Then he went on with his reflections: “I thought that I was rich, with a flower that was unique( 独一无二的 ) in all the world; and all I had was a common rose.
A common rose, and three volcanoes( 火山 ) that come up to my knees—and one of them perhaps extinct( 不再活跃的 ) forever . . . that doesn’t make me a very great prince . . .”
And he lay down in the grass and cried.
It was then that the fox appeared.
“Good morning,” said the fox.
“Good morning,” the little prince responded politely, although when he turned around he saw nothing.
“I am right here,” the voice said, “under the apple tree.”
“Who are you?” asked the little prince, and added, “You are very pretty to look at.”
“I am a fox,” said the fox.
“Come and play with me,” proposed( 提议 ) the little prince. “I am so unhappy.”
“I cannot play with you,” the fox said. “I am not tamed( 被驯化 ).”
“Ah! Please excuse me,” said the little prince.
But, after some thought, he added:
“What does that mean—‘tame( 驯化 )’?”
“You do not live here,” said the fox. “What is it that you are looking for?”
“I am looking for men,” said the little prince. “What does that mean—‘tame( 驯化 )’?”
“Men,” said the fox. “They have guns, and they hunt. It is very disturbing( 令人不安的 ). They also raise chickens. These are their only interests. Are you looking for chickens?”
“No,” said the little prince. “I am looking for friends. What does that mean—‘tame( 驯化 )’?”
“It is an act too often neglected( 被忽略的 ),” said the fox. “It means to establish ties.”
“‘To establish ties’?”
“Just that,” said the fox. “To me, you are still nothing more than a little boy who is just like a hundred thousand other little boys.
And I have no need of you. And you, on your part, have no need of me. To you, I am nothing more than a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes.
But if you tame( 驯化 ) me, then we shall need each other. To me, you will be unique( 独一无二的 ) in all the world. To you, I shall be unique( 独一无二的 ) in all the world . . .”
“I am beginning to understand,” said the little prince. “There is a flower . . . I think that she has tamed( 驯化 ) me . . .”
“It is possible,” said the fox. “On the Earth one sees all sorts of things.”
“Oh, but this is not on the Earth!” said the little prince. The fox seemed perplexed( 困惑的 ), and very curious.
“On another planet?”
“Yes.”
“Are there hunters on this planet?”
“No.”
“Ah, that is interesting! Are there chickens?”
“No.”
“Nothing is perfect,” sighed the fox.
But he came back to his idea. “My life is very monotonous( 单调乏味的 ),” the fox said. “I hunt chickens; men hunt me. All the chickens are just alike, and all the men are just alike.
And, in consequence, I am a little bored. But if you tame( 驯化 ) me, it will be as if the sun came to shine on my life.
I shall know the sound of a step that will be different from all the others. Other steps send me hurrying back underneath the ground.
Yours will call me, like music, out of my burrow( 洞穴 ). And then look: you see the grain-fields down yonder( 在远处 )?
I do not eat bread. Wheat is of no use to me. The wheat fields have nothing to say to me. And that is sad.
But you have hair that is the color of gold. Think how wonderful that will be when you have tamed( 驯化 ) me!
The grain, which is also golden, will bring me back the thought of you. And I shall love to listen to the wind in the wheat . . .”
The fox gazed( 凝视 ) at the little prince, for a long time.
“Please—tame( 驯化 ) me!” he said.
“I want to, very much,” the little prince replied. “But I have not much time. I have friends to discover, and a great many things to understand.”
“One only understands the things that one tames( 驯化 ),” said the fox. “Men have no more time to understand anything. They buy things already made at the shops.
But there is no shop anywhere where one can buy friendship, and so men have no friends any more. If you want a friend, tame( 驯化 ) me . . .”
“What must I do, to tame( 驯化 ) you?” asked the little prince.
“You must be very patient,” replied the fox. “First you will sit down at a little distance from me—like that—in the grass.
I shall look at you out of the corner of my eye, and you will say nothing. Words are the source of misunderstandings. But you will sit a little closer to me, every day . . .”

article_info.previous: 小王子从地理学家那里得知他的花儿生命短暂，他在伤心难过之中接受了地理学家的建议，来到了地球。而在地球的一片沙漠上，他遇见了一条蛇。
article_info.share_words: But if you tame me, then we shall need each other. To me, you will be unique in all the world. To you, I shall be unique in all the world . . .

question.cn: 小王子为什么要爬上高山？
question.en: Why did the little prince climb up a high mountain?

options.en: Because he wanted to find flowers.
Because he wanted to find people.
Because he wanted to have fun.

analysis: 原文提到：“From a mountain as high as this one,” he said to himself, “I shall be able to see the whole planet at one glance, and all the people . . .”所以答案为B。

question.cn: 为什么小王子在看见花园里的玫瑰后感到很难过？
question.en: Why did the little prince feel sad after seeing roses in the garden?

options.cn: 因为那些玫瑰花快要枯萎了。
options.en: Because those roses were about to wither.

options.cn: 因为他发现他的玫瑰不是宇宙中唯一的一朵。
options.en: Because he found that his rose was not the only one in the universe.

analysis: 原文提到：And he was overcome with sadness. His flower had told him that she was the only one of her kind in all the universe. And here were five thousand of them, all alike, in one single garden! 所以答案为C。

question.en: What did the fox ask the little prince to do?

options.cn: 狐狸想让小王子驯化他。
options.en: The fox wanted the little prince to tame him.

options.cn: 狐狸想让小王子离开他。
options.en: The fox wanted the little prince to leave him.

options.cn: 狐狸想让小王子给他点水喝。
options.en: The fox wanted the little prince to give him some water.

analysis: 原文提到：The fox gazed at the little prince, for a long time. “Please—tame me!” he said. 所以答案为A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第10天
